Award.AwardTitle: Proposal to Support Participation of Junior Scientists from the US in International School on Physics of Indirect Excitons
Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to support the direct expenses of young faculty, postdocs
and graduate students from the US for their participation in the International School on Physics
of Indirect Excitons that will take place on July 26 - August 1, 2014, in the Ettore Majorana
Center, Erice, Italy. We propose supporting about five or six junior scientists, graduate
students, and postdocs from US institutions. This International School is an excellent opportunity
for junior scientists from the US to learn about world-class research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Indirect excitons are bosonic quasi-particles in semiconductors with unique properties: they have long lifetime and spin-relaxation time, can travel over large distances before recombination, can be cooled down to low temperatures to form a quantum gas, and can be controlled by voltage in-situ. Due to these properties, indirect excitons represent a model system for both the studies of fundamental properties of light and matter and the development of conceptually new excitonic devices.

 

This project supported the direct expenses of graduate students from the US for their participation in the International School on Physics of Indirect Excitons on July 26 - August 1, 2014, in the Ettore Majorana Center, Erice, Italy. The School addressed fundamental physics of cold bosons in solid state materials, novel principles for optoelectronic devices, and new systems with indirect excitons. With the support of this project, four graduate students from the US participated in the International School on Physics of Indirect Excitons. The students got an opportunity to participate in the major event in the field of indirect excitons, to exchange knowledge with their European colleagues, to attend lectures and talks on excitons, and to present posters and short talks at the International School on Physics of Indirect Excitons.
